translated: Elder’s Birth Stories
The Chapter with Nāgas and Samālas
The Elder Bhisāluvadāyaka’s Birth Story
“Having gone to the forest, the pleasure grove,
I lived in the wilderness.
I saw the Buddha Vipassī,
the receiver of offerings.
I offered him a bhisālu fruit🔽and water for washing his hands.
Having bowed my head to his feet,
I left, facing north.
For ninety-one eons,
that offering of a bhisālu fruit;
I do not know of any bad destination,
this is the fruit of that good deed.
In the third eon from now,
I will be a well-regarded noble,
endowed with the seven treasures,
a powerful universal monarch.
The four analytical insights …
… the Buddha’s instruction has been accomplished.”🔽Thus did the Elder Bhisāluvadāyaka recite this verse.

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā bhisāluvadāyako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.🔽Bhisāluvadāyakattherassāpadānaṁ catutthaṁ.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā bhisāluvadāyakaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati  bhisāluvadāyaka therassa apadānam catuttha
translated: The Elder Bhisāluvadāyaka’s Birth Story is the fourth.
The sixth recitation section.
